name: limonium-carolinianum
country-or-region-of-origin: Eastern Canada, east coast of U.S.A., Mexico
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
flower-description: The flowers are very small, purple with white sepals, sepals may remain after the flower is gone. Blooms in clusters July to Aug.
leaf-description: Leaves are simple, basal with entire margins. Leaves ovate, 7-8 inches long, green, leathery, hairy, forming a rosette at the bottom of the main stem.
stem-description: The stem is erect, green to redish, stiff, highly branched with alternating secondary stems
uses: Used in making wreaths. The roots contain tannin and are powerfully astringent. A decoction of the root has long been used as a popular domestic remedy for diarrhea, dysentery, etc and is also used to treat sore mouths, cankers, etc. The dried and powdered root is applied to old ulcers or piles.
